titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Laissez Faire Books records
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Loralee Sepsey

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-07-08T15:20-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: <date calendar="gregorian" normal="20120113" era="ce">January 13, 2012</date><item>Revised to add increment</item>

did.abstract: Correspondence, memoranda, financial documents, catalogs, other printed matter, and photographs relating to libertarianism and publishing in the United States.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Laissez Faire Books records, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2007.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Laissez Faire Books opens in New York City, founded by John Muller and Sharon Presley.
Andrea and Howard Rich buy Laissez Faire Books.
Laissez Faire Books moves to San Francisco, California.
Laissez Faire Books reaches peak revenue of $1.3 million per year.
Laissez Faire Books goes bankrupt and is sold to the Foundation for Economic Education.

eventgrp.event: Laissez Faire Books is sold back to Andrea and Howard Rich.
Andrea Rich gives Kathleen Nelson Laissez Faire Books, and it is relocated to Little Rock, Arkansas.
Laissez Faire Books announces it is going out of business.
Laissez Faire Books is sold to the International Society for Individual Liberty.

chronitem.event: Laissez Faire Books is sold to Agora Financial LLC, and is currently still operating under this company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, financial records, serial issues, photographs, and other printed matter relating to libertarianism and book publishing in the United States.

did.unittitle: "Memorial Service for Roy A. Childs, Jr.,"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains miscellaneous printed matter such as a CD catalogue for Roy A. Childs's memorial service, a customer survey, postcard templates, and job listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains issues of the Laissez Faire Books catalog, newspaper articles, lists, notes, and other printed matter relating to the objectivist author Ayn Rand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, stationery, financial documents, and other printed matter relating to the magazine Critical Review, a project involving Laissez Faire co-owner Howard Rich.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs, correspondence, essays, and other printed matter relating to Laissez Faire Book's outreach into Eastern European countries, such as Czechoslovakia, Ukraine, Poland, Hungary, and Romania, post-communism as an attempt to promote libertarianism. They established an outpost of Laissez Faire Books in Bucharest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains invitations, guest lists, pamphlets, photographs, and other printed matter relating to social and fundraising events held or attended by Laissez Faire Books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains pamphlets, newsletters, profiles, and other printed matter relating to feminism and the Association of Libertarian Feminists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains speeches, notes, correspondence, pamphlets, and other printed matter relating to a talk Laissez Faire co-owner Andrea Rich gave at Hillsdale College in Hillsdale, Michigan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains several flyers about the Laissez Faire Book Club, a positive selection mailing list that allowed members to pick and choose their monthly book mailing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, artwork, notes, and other printed matter relating to the development of the Laissez Faire Books website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains newsletters, pamphlets, and other printed matter from various libertarian institutes, such as the Cato Institute, the John Locke Society, and Libertarians Futurist Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains newsletters, articles, and other printed matter relating to Nathaniel Branden, former lover of Ayn Rand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains mailings, catalogs, and other printed matter relating to Palo Alto Book Service, a distributor of books that was based in Palo Alto, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, guest lists, pamphlets, nomination packets, and other printed matter relating to the Thomas Szasz Award for Outstanding Contributions to the Cause for Civil Liberties.
